author: mklement0
body:
# Summary of the new feature/enhancement

<sup>Related: #11607</sup>

PS Core added the ability to pass calculated properties to `Measure-Object -Property`  - see #6855

However, the current implementation is inconsistent with how calculated properties work in other cmdlets, such as `Select-Object` (something I originally neglected to consider):

* You can only pass a _script block_, not also a _hashtable_ whose `Expression` entry contains 

* Since you cannot pass a hashtable, you also cannot _name_ the calculated property (key `Name` or `Label`), causing the _script block's definition text_ to appear as the `.Property` value in the output.

**The only thing you can do now - pass a _script block_:**

```powershell
# Count the odd numbers  in the input.
PS> 1, 2, 3 | Measure-Object -Sum -Property { $_ % 2 }
Count             : 3
Average           : 
Sum               : 2
Maximum           : 
Minimum           : 
StandardDeviation : 
Property          :  $_ % 2    # !!
```

Note how `$_ % 2` - the verbatim definition of the script block - became the name of the calculated property in the output object's `.Property` value.

**What you should be able to do as well: pass a _hashtable_ that gives the property a name:**

```powershell
# WISHFUL THINKING
PS> 1, 2, 3 | Measure-Object -Sum -Property @{ Name='OddNumbers'; Expression={$_ % 2 } }
Count             : 3
Average           : 
Sum               : 2
Maximum           : 
Minimum           : 
StandardDeviation : 
Property          :  OddNumbers
```

Note that this would be a safe change, because attempting to pass a hashtable currently fails.


Written as of PowerShell Core 7.0.0-rc.2.
title: Calculated properties for Measure-Object should support hashtable syntax with naming
